title: Authors and Citation
text: Balamuta J (2023). visualize: Graph Probability Distributions User Supplied Parameters Statistics. R package version 4.5.0, https://thecoatlessprofessor.com/projects/visualize/, https://r-pkg.thecoatlessprofessor.com/visualize/, https://github.com/coatless-rpkg/visualize.
code: @Manual{,   title = {visualize: Graph Probability Distributions with User Supplied Parameters and Statistics},   author = {James Balamuta},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 4.5.0, https://thecoatlessprofessor.com/projects/visualize/, https://r-pkg.thecoatlessprofessor.com/visualize/},   url = {https://github.com/coatless-rpkg/visualize}, }

what: Graph Probability Distributions with User Supplied Parameters and Statistics
title: Graph Probability Distributions with User Supplied Parameters and Statistics
text: goal visualize graph pdf pmf highlight area probability present user defined locations. Visualize able provide lower tail, bounded, upper tail, two tail calculations. Supports strict equal inequalities. Also provided graph mean variance distribution.

title: Graph Probability Distributions with User Supplied Parameters and Statistics
text: can install released version visualize CRAN : development version GitHub :
code: install.packages("visualize") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("coatless/visualize")

title: Graph Probability Distributions with User Supplied Parameters and Statistics
text: use visualize, load package : , construct graph following visualize.dist() pattern. example, normal distribution can shown :    parameters distribution can also modified. Take example Binomial distribution.   Discrete distributions can also handle level strict (<, >) equal (<=, >=) inequality.
code: library("visualize") # Graph a standard normal distribution with a z-score of 1.96 visualize.norm(1.96) # Change the location of the tail visualize.norm(1.96, section = "upper") # Shift the mean and create a bounded range. visualize.norm(c(-1.96, 1.96), section = "bounded") visualize.binom(stat = 9, size = 20, p = 0.5) # Visualize the binominal distribution with a higher size and lower probability. visualize.binom(stat = 9, size = 24, p = 0.25) # Create a strict inequality (lower < x < higher) visualize.pois(stat = c(4, 6), lambda = 3.5, section = "bounded",   strict = c(TRUE, TRUE)) # Allow for equality on either side only on the right side of the bounded region. visualize.pois(stat = c(4, 6), lambda = 3.5, section = "bounded",   strict = c(TRUE, FALSE)) # Allow for equality on either side of the inequality (lower <= x <= higher) visualize.pois(stat = c(4, 6), lambda = 3.5, section = "bounded",   strict = c(FALSE, FALSE))

what: visualize: Graph Probability Distributions with User Supplied Parameters and Statistics — visualize-package
title: visualize: Graph Probability Distributions with User Supplied Parameters and Statistics — visualize-package
text: Graphs pdf pmf highlights area probability present user defined locations. Visualize able provide lower tail, bounded, upper tail, two tail calculations. Supports strict equal inequalities. Also provided graph mean variance distribution.

title: visualize: Graph Probability Distributions with User Supplied Parameters and Statistics — visualize-package
text: Maintainer: James Balamuta james.balamuta@gmail.com (ORCID) [copyright holder]

title: visualize: Graph Probability Distributions with User Supplied Parameters and Statistics — visualize-package
code: ## visualize.it acts as the general wrapper. ## For guided application of visualize, see the visualize.distr_name list. # Binomial distribution evaluated at lower tail. visualize.it(dist = 'binom', stat = 2, params = list(size = 4,prob = .5),              section ="lower", strict = TRUE) visualize.binom(stat = 2, size = 4, prob =.5, section ="lower", strict = TRUE)   # Set to shade inbetween a bounded region. visualize.it(dist = 'norm', stat = c(-1, 1), list(mu = 0, sd = 1), section="bounded") visualize.norm(stat = c(-1, 1), mu = 0, sd = 1, section ="bounded")   # Gamma distribution evaluated at upper tail. visualize.it(dist = 'gamma', stat = 2, params = list(alpha = 2, theta = 1), section="upper") visualize.gamma(stat = 2, alpha = 2, theta = 1, section="upper")

title: Visualize Beta Distribution — visualize.beta
text: Generates plot Beta distribution user specified parameters.

title: Visualize Beta Distribution — visualize.beta
code: visualize.beta(stat = 1, alpha = 3, beta = 2, section = "lower")

title: Visualize Beta Distribution — visualize.beta
text: stat statistic obtain probability . using "bounded" condition, must supply parameter stat = c(lower_bound, upper_bound). Otherwise, simple stat = desired_point suffice. alpha alpha considered shape1 R's implementation beta distribution. alpha must greater 0. beta beta considered shape2 R's implementation beta distribution. beta must greater 0. section Select want statistic(s) evaluated via section= either "lower","bounded", "upper", "tails".

title: Visualize Beta Distribution — visualize.beta
text: Returns plot distribution according conditions supplied.

title: Visualize Beta Distribution — visualize.beta
text: James Balamuta

title: Visualize Beta Distribution — visualize.beta
code: # Evaluates lower tail. visualize.beta(stat = 1, alpha = 2, beta = 3, section = "lower")    # Evaluates bounded region. visualize.beta(stat = c(.5,1), alpha = 4, beta = 3, section = "bounded")    # Evaluates upper tail. visualize.beta(stat = 1, alpha = 2, beta = 3, section = "upper")

title: Visualize Binomial Distribution — visualize.binom
text: Generates plot Binomial distribution user specified parameters.

title: Visualize Binomial Distribution — visualize.binom
code: visualize.binom(   stat = 1,   size = 3,   prob = 0.5,   section = "lower",   strict = FALSE )

title: Visualize Binomial Distribution — visualize.binom
text: stat statistic obtain probability . using "bounded" condition, must supply parameter stat = c(lower_bound, upper_bound). Otherwise, simple stat = desired_point suffice. size size sample. prob probability picking object. section Select want statistic(s) evaluated via section= either "lower","bounded", "upper", "tails". strict Determines whether probability generated strict (<, >) equal (<=, >=) inequality. strict= requires either values = 0 =FALSE equal values =1 =TRUE strict. bounded condition use: strict=c(0,1) strict=c(FALSE,TRUE).

title: Visualize Binomial Distribution — visualize.binom
text: James Balamuta

title: Visualize Binomial Distribution — visualize.binom
code: # Evaluates lower tail with equal to inequality. visualize.binom(stat = 1, size = 3, prob = 0.5, section = "lower", strict = FALSE)    # Evaluates bounded region with lower bound equal to and upper bound strict inequality. visualize.binom(stat = c(1,2), size = 5, prob = 0.35, section = "bounded", strict = c(0,1))   # Evaluates upper tail with strict inequality. visualize.binom(stat = 1, size = 3, prob = 0.5, section = "upper", strict = TRUE)

what: Graphing function for Continuous Distributions. — visualize.continuous
title: Graphing function for Continuous Distributions. — visualize.continuous
text: Handles continuous distributions graphed. Users use function. Instead, users use visualize.().

title: Graphing function for Continuous Distributions. — visualize.continuous
code: visualize.continuous(dist, stat = c(0, 1), params, section = "lower")

title: Graphing function for Continuous Distributions. — visualize.continuous
text: dist contains supported continuos distribution shortname. stat statistic obtain probability . using "bounded" condition, must supply parameter stat = c(lower_bound, upper_bound). Otherwise, simple stat = desired_point suffice. params list must contain necessary parameters distribution. example, params = list(mu = 1, sd = 1) normal distribution mean 1 standard deviation 1. aware parameters distribution, consider using visualize.dist_name functions listed "See Also" section. section Select want statistic(s) evaluated via section= either "lower","bounded", "upper", "tails"

title: Graphing function for Continuous Distributions. — visualize.continuous
text: James Balamuta

title: Graphing function for Continuous Distributions. — visualize.continuous
code: # Function does not have dist look up, must go through visualize.it visualize.it(dist='norm', stat = c(0,1), params = list(mu = 1, sd = 1), section = "bounded")

what: Graphing function for Discrete Distributions. — visualize.discrete
title: Graphing function for Discrete Distributions. — visualize.discrete
text: Handles discrete distributions graphed. Users use function. Instead, users use link{visualize.}.

title: Graphing function for Discrete Distributions. — visualize.discrete
code: visualize.discrete(dist, stat = c(0, 1), params, section = "lower", strict)

title: Graphing function for Discrete Distributions. — visualize.discrete
text: dist contains distribution link{visualize.distributions}. stat statistic obtain probability . using "bounded" condition, must supply parameter stat = c(lower_bound, upper_bound). Otherwise, simple stat = desired_point suffice. params list must contain necessary parameters distribution. example, params = list(n = 5, prob = .25) binomial distribution size 5 probability .75. aware parameters distribution, consider using visualize.dist_name functions listed "See Also" section. section Select want statistic(s) evaluated via section= either "lower","bounded", "upper", "tails". strict Determines whether probability generated strict (<, >) equal (<=, >=) inequality. strict= requires either values = 0 =FALSE equal values =1 =TRUE strict. bounded condition use: strict=c(0,1) strict=c(FALSE,TRUE).

title: Graphing function for Discrete Distributions. — visualize.discrete
text: James Balamuta

title: Graphing function for Discrete Distributions. — visualize.discrete
code: # Function does not have dist look up, must go through visualize.it visualize.it(dist='geom', stat = c(2,4), params = list(prob = .75), section = "bounded",           strict = c(0,1))

title: Visualize's Supported Distributions — visualize.distributions
text: visualize's supported distributions density, probability, quantile functions. addition, mean variance functions present. descriptors also exist documented .

title: Visualize's Supported Distributions — visualize.distributions
code: visualize.distributions

title: Visualize's Supported Distributions — visualize.distributions
text: Distributions loaded following format: distributions currently available use : denotes distribution added v2.0.

title: Visualize's Supported Distributions — visualize.distributions
text: James Balamuta

title: Visualize's Supported Distributions — visualize.distributions
code: visualize.distributions = list(   'beta' = list(     type = "continuous",     name = "Beta Distribution",     variable = "b",     varsymbols = c("\u03B1","\u03B2"),     params = 2,     init  = function(params, ...) {       shape1 = params[[1]]; shape2 = params[[2]]       if(shape1 <= 0 || shape2 <= 0) stop("Error: Need alpha, beta  > 0")       mean = shape1 / (shape1 + shape2)       var = (shape1 * shape2)/((shape1 + shape2 + 1)*(shape1 + shape2)^2)       c(mean, var)     },     density = function(x,params, ncp = 0, lower.tail = TRUE, log = FALSE, ...){       if(params[[1]] <= 0 || params[[2]] <= 0) stop("Error: Need alpha, beta  > 0")         dbeta(x,params[[1]], params[[2]], ncp = ncp, log = log)     },     probability = function(q,params, ncp = 0, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE, ...){       if(params[[1]] <= 0 || params[[2]] <= 0) stop("Error: Need alpha, beta  > 0")       pbeta(q,params[[1]], params[[2]], ncp = ncp, lower.tail = lower.tail, log.p = log.p)     },     quantile = function(p,params, ncp = 0, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE, ...){       if(params[[1]] <= 0 || params[[2]] <= 0) stop("Error: Need alpha, beta  > 0")       qbeta(p,params[[1]], params[[2]], ncp = ncp, lower.tail = lower.tail, log.p = log.p)     }   ) )

title: Visualize Hypergeometric Distribution — visualize.hyper
text: stat statistic obtain probability . using "bounded" condition, must supply parameter stat = c(lower_bound, upper_bound). Otherwise, simple stat = desired_point suffice. m m white balls. m must greater 0. n n black balls. n must greater 0. k draw k balls without replacement. section Select want statistic(s) evaluated via section= either "lower","bounded", "upper", "tails". strict Determines whether probability generated strict (<, >) equal (<=, >=) inequality. strict= requires either values = 0 =FALSE equal values =1 =TRUE strict. bounded condition use: strict=c(0,1) strict=c(FALSE,TRUE).

title: Visualize Hypergeometric Distribution — visualize.hyper
text: James Balamuta

title: Visualize Hypergeometric Distribution — visualize.hyper
code: # Evaluates lower tail. visualize.hyper(stat = 1, m=4, n=5, k=3, section = "lower", strict = 0)    # Evaluates bounded region. visualize.hyper(stat = c(2,4), m=14, n=5, k=2, section = "bounded", strict = c(0,1))   # Evaluates upper tail. visualize.hyper(stat = 1, m=4, n=5, k=3, section = "upper", strict = 1)

title: Visualize's Processing Function — visualize.it
text: Acts director traffic first line error handling regarding submitted visualization requests. function used advanced users.

title: Visualize's Processing Function — visualize.it
code: visualize.it(   dist = "norm",   stat = c(0, 1),   params = list(mu = 0, sd = 1),   section = "lower",   strict = c(0, 1) )

title: Visualize's Processing Function — visualize.it
text: dist string contain supported probability distributions name R. Supported continuous distributions: "beta", "chisq", "exp", "gamma", "norm", "unif". Supported discrete distributions: "binom", "geom", "hyper", "nbinom", "pois". stat statistic obtain probability . using "bounded" condition, must supply parameter stat = c(lower_bound, upper_bound). Otherwise, simple stat = desired_point suffice. params list must contain necessary parameters distribution. example, params = list(mu = 1, sd = 1) normal distribution mean 1 standard deviation 1. aware parameters distribution, consider using visualize.dist functions listed "See Also" section. section Select want statistic(s) evaluated via section= either "lower","bounded", "upper", "tails". strict Determines whether probability generated strict (<, >) equal (<=, >=) inequality. strict= requires either values = 0 =FALSE strict values =1 =TRUE equal . bounded condition use: strict=c(0,1) strict=c(FALSE,TRUE).

title: Visualize's Processing Function — visualize.it
text: Returns plot distribution according conditions supplied.

title: Visualize's Processing Function — visualize.it
text: http://cran.r-project.org/web/views/Distributions.html

title: Visualize's Processing Function — visualize.it
text: James Balamuta

title: Visualize's Processing Function — visualize.it
code: # Defaults to lower tail evaluation visualize.it(dist = 'norm', stat = 1, list(mu = 3 , sd = 2), section = "lower")   # Set to evaluate the upper tail. visualize.it(dist = 'norm', stat = 1, list(mu=3,sd=2),section="upper")   # Set to shade inbetween a bounded region. visualize.it(dist = 'norm', stat = c(-1,1), list(mu=0,sd=1), section="bounded")   # Gamma distribution evaluated at upper tail. visualize.it(dist = 'gamma', stat = 2, params = list(alpha=2,beta=1),section="upper")   # Binomial distribution evaluated at lower tail. visualize.it('binom', stat = 2, params = list(n=4,p=.5))

text: stat statistic obtain probability . using "bounded" condition, must supply parameter stat = c(lower_bound, upper_bound). Otherwise, simple stat = desired_point suffice. starting point. Note: <b b end point. Note: b > section Select want statistic(s) evaluated via section= either "lower","bounded", "upper", "tails".

title: Visualize Uniform Distribution — visualize.unif
text: James Balamuta

title: Visualize Uniform Distribution — visualize.unif
code: # Evaluates lower tail. visualize.unif(stat = 8.75, a = 7, b = 10, section = "lower")    # Evaluates bounded region. visualize.unif(stat = c(3,6), a = 1, b = 7, section = "bounded")   # Evaluates upper tail. visualize.unif(stat = 2, a = 1, b = 5, section = "upper")

title: Visualize Cauchy Distribution — visualize.wilcox
text: Generates plot Wilcoxon Rank Sum distribution user specified parameters.

title: Visualize Cauchy Distribution — visualize.wilcox
code: visualize.wilcox(stat = 1, m = 7, n = 3, section = "lower")

title: Visualize Cauchy Distribution — visualize.wilcox
text: stat statistic obtain probability . using "bounded" condition, must supply parameter stat = c(lower_bound, upper_bound). Otherwise, simple stat = desired_point suffice. m Sample size group 1. n Sample size group 2. section Select want statistic(s) evaluated via section= either "lower","bounded", "upper", "tails".

title: Visualize Cauchy Distribution — visualize.wilcox
text: Returns plot distribution according conditions supplied.

title: Visualize Cauchy Distribution — visualize.wilcox
text: James Balamuta

title: Visualize Cauchy Distribution — visualize.wilcox
code: # Evaluates lower tail. visualize.wilcox(stat = 1, m = 7, n = 3, section = "lower")    # Evaluates bounded region. visualize.wilcox(stat = c(2,3), m = 5, n = 4, section = "bounded")    # Evaluates upper tail. visualize.wilcox(stat = 1, m = 7, n = 3, section = "upper")

title: visualize 4.5.0 - Hotfix - “Seeing is Greek”
text: Removed unicode display variables inequalities per CRAN request. Increased required R version v4.0.0. Switched deployment Travis GitHub Actions Added pkgdown website.

text: CRAN release: 2020-01-08

title: visualize 4.3.0 - Hotfix - “Seeing is Modern”
text: Switched NEWS NEWS.md take advantage Markdown formatting. (#5) Switched README use README.Rmd, generates README.md. (#4) Added links GitHub repository DESCRIPTION file

title: visualize 4.3.0 - Hotfix - “Seeing is Modern”
text: Corrected outstanding CRAN checks related malformed DESCRIPTION file need import functions (#3)

title: visualize 4.2.0 - Hotfix - “Seeing is Educational”
text: big thanks Psychology Drs. Sharon Klinkenberg University Amsterdam, reported many bugs addressed release!

title: visualize 4.2.0 - Hotfix - “Seeing is Educational”
text: Supply 1 statistic bounded tails condition now stops program generating graph. console, user receive: “Supplied stat length < 2 section=”<bounded,tails>” requires two statistics. Please resubmit parameter stat=c(lower,upper).” Supply 2 statistics request bounded tails condition now stops program generating graph. console, users receive: “Supplied stat length > 1 section=”<lower,upper>” requires one statistic. Please resubmit stat=your_test_statistic.” Supply 1 strict value discrete distributions request bounded tails, strict value apply ends. console, users receive: “Supplied strict length < 2, setting inequalities ”<strict, equal >” inequality.” warning now issued requesting tails option nonsymmetric distribution.

title: visualize 4.2.0 - Hotfix - “Seeing is Educational”
text: Area F distribution now render reliably underneath probability density function plot. F Distribution correctly renders F-Statistic instead T-Statistic. F Distribution’s parameters (df1,df2) now correctly rendered. test statistic continuous distribution begins graph’s bounds, graph render without highlighted area. graphs involving nonsymmertric distributions now begin x-axis 0.

title: visualize 4.1.0 - Hotfix - “Seeing is Windowed”
text: Documentation longer disappear screen.

title: visualize 4.0.0 - Live Update - “Seeing is Split”
text: Two tail evaluations continuous discrete distributions! Highlighted shading continuous distributions! Start End markers test statistic(s) x-axis!

title: visualize 4.0.0 - Live Update - “Seeing is Split”
text: Updated visualize. functions account new section request.

title: visualize 3.0.0 - Live Update - “Seeing is Strict”

title: visualize 3.0.0 - Live Update - “Seeing is Strict”

title: visualize 2.0.0 - Live Update - “Seeing is Believing”
text: Support following Continuous Distributions: Cauchy, F, Log Normal, Logistic, T, Wilcox. Bar graph rendering discrete probability distributions.

title: visualize 2.0.0 - Live Update - “Seeing is Believing”
text: Rewritten Distribution Wrapper

title: visualize 1.0.0 - Live Update - “Seeing is Magic”
text: Graph PDF PMF probability function determine probability enclosed. See characteristics distribution requested (Parameters, Mean, Variance). Supported Continuous Distributions: Chi-squared, beta, gamma, exponential, uniform, normal. Supported Discrete Distributions: Geometric, binomial, poisson, hypergeometric, negative binomial.

title: visualize 1.0.0 - Live Update - “Seeing is Magic”
text: Visualize made independent study project learn creating r-packages explore probability distributions approved mentored Statistics Professor Jeffrey Douglas University Illinois Urbana-Champaign (UIUC).
